DataElement.preferredName: Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) Problems Make It Difficult to Do Work Take Care of Things at Home or Get Along with Other People 4 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A person's stated observation of how difficult the problems they identified in the questionnaire made it for them to do their work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people, using a four point Likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Health Questionnaire - 9 Item Last Two Weeks How Often Problems Make It Difficult to Do Work Take Care of Things at Home or Get Along with Other People
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A 9-item scale using each of the 9 DSM-IV criteria with self-reported frequency of "0" (not at all) to "3" (nearly every day). One of the most widely used instruments to assess depression, PHQ-9 scores of 5, 10, 15, and 20 represent mild, moderate, moderately severe, and severe depression, respectively._Coming after all others in time or space or degree or being the only one remaining._A natural number greater than 1 and less than 3 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of one and one._Any period of seven consecutive days._The number of occurrences of something within a given time period. (NCI)_A question about how difficult an individual's problems have made it to do their work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A standardized survey developed and published by Kurt Kroenke, Robert Spitzer and Janet Williams in 2001 in the Journal of General Internal Medicine which is used to measure the severity of an individual's depression symptoms. This instrument contains 9 items with a follow-up question that is not part of the scoring. Each item is rated on a scale of 0-3 with 0 being 'not at all' and 3 being 'nearly every day.'

Concepts.definition: A 9-item scale using each of the 9 DSM-IV criteria with self-reported frequency of "0" (not at all) to "3" (nearly every day). One of the most widely used instruments to assess depression, PHQ-9 scores of 5, 10, 15, and 20 represent mild, moderate, moderately severe, and severe depression, respectively.
